Duality of deconfined quantum critical point in two dimensional Dirac semimetals

Jiang Zhou jzhou5@gzu.edu.cn Department of Physics, Guizhou University, Guiyang 550025, PR China    Ya-jie Wu School of Science, Xi’an Technological University, Xi’an 710032, PR China    Su-Peng Kou spkou@bnu.edu.cn Department of Physics, Beijing Normal University, Beijing 100875, PR China
Abstract

In this paper we discuss the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el and Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} valence bond solids quantum criticality in graphene Dirac semimetal. Considering the quartic four-fermion interaction g​(ψ¯i​Γi​j​ψj)2𝑔superscriptsubscript¯𝜓𝑖subscriptΓ𝑖𝑗subscript𝜓𝑗2g(\bar{\psi}_{i}\Gamma_{ij}\psi_{j})^{2} that contains spin,valley, and sublattice degrees of freedom in the continuum field theory, we find the microscopic symmetry is spontaneously broken when the coupling g𝑔g is greater than a critical value gcsubscript𝑔𝑐g_{c}. The symmetry breaking gaps out the fermion and leads to semimetal-insulator transition. All possible quartic fermion-bilinear interactions give rise to the uniform critical coupling, which exhibits the multicritical point for various orders and the Landau-forbidden quantum critical point. We also investigate the typical critical point between Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el and Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} valence bond solid transition when the symmetry is broken. The quantum criticality is captured by the Wess-Zumino-Witten term and there exist a mutual-duality for Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS order. We show the emergent spinon in the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS transition , from which we conclude the phase transition is a deconfined quantum critical point. Additionally, the connection between the index theorem and zero energy mode bounded by the topological defect in the Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS phase is studied to reveal the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS duality.

I Introduction

The study of quantum phases of matter and the phase transition in strongly correlated systems is one of the central issues of modern condensed matter physics sdev ; qi0 ; hasan ; fu ; read . In past seven years, the semimetal phases have attracted extensive attentions. In topological Weyl/Dirac semimetals, the conduction and valence bands cross at zero-dimensional nodal pointsweng ; weng1 ; weng2 ; wan ; vish ; xsy ; lbq ; hou , but for topological nodal line semimetals, it crosses at one-dimensional nodal line(see Refs. cw, ; wz, and references therein). Recently, based on the 2D and 3D semimetal, the fermion-boson mixed system was proposed to describe the Landau-forbidden quantum phase transition, which gives rise to Fermion-induced quantum critical points(FIQCP)yao ; yao1 ; yao2 ; yyz and fluctuation-induced continuous phase transition with hidden degrees of freedom herbut1 ; herbut2 ; herbut3 . The FIQCP is type-II Landau-forbidden transitions and the type-I is deconfined quantum critical point in quantum magnettsen . In addition, the fermion-boson mixed system have been shown to provide us well understanding of space-time supersymmetry at quantum critical point(QCP)gro ; lee ; yao3 .

Graphene is a Dirac semimetal phase, and the low energy quasiparticle excitations are described by (2+1) dimensions field theory of free Dirac fermions. Due to the special relativistic dispersion, the graphenelike structure provides a platform for realization of many quantum electrodynamics predictions(e.g. Klein tunneling geim , Zitterbewegung effect kat ). When suffering from perturbations or electron correlation, the semimetal opens a fermion gap and leads to rich phases of matter. For example, the integer quantum Hall state is obtained by introducing the next-nearest neighbor hopping with complex phases but without net magnetic flux threads each hexagonal plaquette haldane , ℤ2subscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}_{2} quantum spin Hall effect with time reversal symmetry could be obtained in a similar way kane . The charge density wave, Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} dimerization(Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} valence-bond-solid), and spin density wave are known orders that gap out the fermion spectrum kou1 ; cham . Also, the fermi-boson coupling gaps out the fermion and leads to the surprising fractional charge cham ; mudry ; franz ; jack . It’s shown that the semimetal exhibits exotic topological phasesxu1 ; xu2 and the non-Landau-Ginzburg-Wilson transitionyyz ; herbut1 ; ass with electron correlation and emergent fluctuation. The fluctuation with emergent degree of freedom gives rise to the rich quantum criticality behavior and the various QCP is shown to belong to the Gross-Neveu-Yukawa(GNY) universality classherbut3 ; herbut4 ; herbut5 ; herbut6 ; gn . Meanwhile, recent large-scale quantum Monte Carlo simulations have confirmed that the quantum criticality in interacting Dirac semimetals is consistent with the Gross-Neveu universality classass1 ; ass2 ; yo .

In this paper, by using the nonlinear sigma model field theory tan ; hx ; tsen2 ; egm ; yao4 , we understand the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el and Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} valence-bond-solid(VBS) quantum criticality in Dirac semimetals. Our motivation is stated as follows. Recently, Ref.yao, have studied the semimetal-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS transition, and shown the evidence of a deconfined quantum critical point between the Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS and antiferromagnetic phases of S​U​(N)𝑆𝑈𝑁SU(N) fermions model on the honeycomb lattice(N=2𝑁2N=2 is the flavors of four-component Dirac fermions). All the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el and Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS are gapped quantum phases, the induced mass-gap corresponds to the modulation of the fermion bilinear. The coupling between the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS fermion bilinear and the fermion fields leads to the purely bosonic fields theory for competing Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS orders. From the corresponding dynamical of bosonic fields, the quantum criticality will be easily identified. The phase transition is shown to associate with a emergent spinon and gauge field at the critical point, so the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS transition indeed a deconfined QCP.

The mass-gap equivalent to the dynamical symmetry breaking-induced massive fermion and the (2+1)21(2+1) GNY theory is crucial for the mass-gap generation. In correlated many-body systems, we often encounter the Yukawa terms that driven by short range fermion-fermion interacting. For mass generation and competing phase in interacting systems, the instability of interacting play a key role. Apart from the short range Coulomb interaction gama , the general four-body interaction in graphene semimetals includes the quartic fermion bilinear that mixed the spin, valley, and sublattice. When the symmetry is broken, the general fermion bilinear generates various mass matrices that anticommute with each other. The physical explanation of these mass matrices have been established in Ref.ryu, . We will show there exists multicritical point for possible orders, and the multicritical point only depend on the dimensions of the mass matrix. The emergence of two symmetry-unrelated orders at a critical point display the Landau-beyond quantum criticality, and the effective action for a set of anticommutating orders may be derived upon integrating over the fermion fields weigman . Under such formalism, the quantum criticality and the quantum phase transition between different phases can be readily understood.

As shown in the text, the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el and Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS orders at the critical point are dual to each other, and the topological excitation or topological defect also share the duality in two phases. The topological defect bounds midgap fermion spectrum(i.e. zero energy mode) in the core is well known for fermi-boson mixed field theory. Jackiw and Rossi have studied the fermion-vortex system with fermion-scalar field interaction, and point that the Dirac equation possesses |n|𝑛|n| zero-eigenvalue modes in the n𝑛n -vorticity background field jack2 . This result has been proven associate with a index theoremweinberg . The fermion zero mode has caused great interests in various condensed matter systems gura ; cheng ; jack3 . Here, we study the zero energy mode bounded by the topological texture in Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS phase as a complementary study. And more importantly, we study the index of the topological excitation beyond any symmetries in the sense of Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS duality.

The paper is organized as follows. The dynamical gap equation is established in sec. II. From the gap equation, we solve uniform critical coupling constant for possible broken orders. In Sec. III, the typical Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS transition is studied. We derive the Wess-Zumino-Witten action for five-component Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS order vector and discuss the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS mutual duality. In Sec. IV, we study the index theorem of zero energy mode in Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS state to reveal the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS mutual duality. In the end, we give a summary in Sec. V.

II gap generation and symmetry

II.1 Gap generation

The microscopic symmetry may be spontaneously broke and lead to semimetal-insulator transition in graphene-like Dirac semimetal. Thus, started from a four-fermions interaction, the insulator can be builded from a nonvanishing fermion bilinear at mean field level. The nonzero fermion bilinear will lead to the mass-gap for the insulating phase, we consider the following continuum field theory

S​(ψ¯i,ψi)=∫d3​x​[ψ¯i​γμ​i​∂μψi+g2​N​(ψ¯i​Γa​ψj)2],𝑆subscript¯𝜓𝑖subscript𝜓𝑖superscript𝑑3𝑥delimited-[]subscript¯𝜓𝑖superscript𝛾𝜇𝑖subscript𝜇subscript𝜓𝑖𝑔2𝑁superscriptsubscript¯𝜓𝑖subscriptΓ𝑎subscript𝜓𝑗2S(\bar{\psi}_{i},\psi_{i})=\int d^{3}x\left[\bar{\psi}_{i}\gamma^{\mu}i\partial_{\mu}\psi_{i}+\frac{g}{2N}(\bar{\psi}_{i}\Gamma_{a}\psi_{j})^{2}\right], (5)

where g𝑔g labels the coupling strength for four-fermion interaction, and we have defined ψ¯i≡ψi†​γ0subscript¯𝜓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑖†superscript𝛾0\bar{\psi}_{i}\equiv\psi_{i}^{{\dagger}}\gamma^{0}. The three gamma matrices read

γ0=β=s0​τ0​σ3,γ1=β​α1=s0​τ3​(i​σ1),γ2=β​α2=s0​τ3​(i​σ2),formulae-sequencesuperscript𝛾0𝛽subscript𝑠0subscript𝜏0subscript𝜎3superscript𝛾1𝛽subscript𝛼1subscript𝑠0subscript𝜏3𝑖subscript𝜎1superscript𝛾2𝛽subscript𝛼2subscript𝑠0subscript𝜏3𝑖subscript𝜎2\displaystyle\begin{split}\gamma^{0}=\beta=s_{0}\tau_{0}\sigma_{3},\\ \gamma^{1}=\beta\alpha_{1}=s_{0}\tau_{3}(i\sigma_{1}),\\ \gamma^{2}=\beta\alpha_{2}=s_{0}\tau_{3}(i\sigma_{2}),\end{split} (6)

This Largrangian is similar to the Gross-Neven model with discrete chiral symmetry that used to discuss the mass generation of the gauged vector mesons in particle physicsgn . The gap generation or order profiles can be studied by rewriting the functional integrals as

This means that the mass-gap is irrelevent to the ultraviolet cut-off ΛΛ\Lambda and the running coupling g𝑔g, this should be, because the fermion mass term must be a renormalization group invariant.

II.2 Mass matrix and symmetry classification

When the symmetry is spontaneously broken, the matrix ϕ​Γaitalic-ϕsubscriptΓ𝑎\phi\Gamma_{a} opens a fermion gap at two Dirac points. As shown above, the kinetic part allow 161616 mass matrices, and each corresponds to an insulating phase. To find the physical explanation of these matrices, it’s useful to define the following chiral symmetry time reversal symmetry. For the Hamiltonian with lattice fermion residing on different sublattice, flipping the sign of one sublattice(for example sublattice-b) will reverse the overall sign of the Hamiltonian. The mapping of postive energy to negative energy can be implemented by the operator Θ=s0​τ3​σ3,Θsubscript𝑠0subscript𝜏3subscript𝜎3\Theta=s_{0}\tau_{3}\sigma_{3}, and this symmetry named sublattice symmetry(SLS) or chiral symmetry. If a chiral order parameter is presented, the Hamiltonian preserve SLS when satisfy

Θ​H​(k)​Θ−1=−H​(k).Θ𝐻𝑘superscriptΘ1𝐻𝑘\Theta H(k)\Theta^{-1}=-H(k). (13)

The time reversal is defined as T​c↑+=c↓−𝑇subscript𝑐↑absentsubscript𝑐↓absentTc_{\uparrow+}=c_{\downarrow-}, T​c↓+=−c↑−𝑇subscript𝑐↓absentsubscript𝑐↑absentTc_{\downarrow+}=-c_{\uparrow-}, and which can be implemented by the matrix 𝒯=i​s2​τ1​σ1.𝒯𝑖subscript𝑠2subscript𝜏1subscript𝜎1\mathcal{T}=is_{2}\tau_{1}\sigma_{1.} The Hamiltonian preserve time reverse symmetry(TRS) when satisfy

𝒯​H∗​(−k)​𝒯−1=H​(k).𝒯superscript𝐻∗𝑘superscript𝒯1𝐻𝑘\mathcal{T}H^{\ast}(-k)\mathcal{T}^{-1}=H(k). (14)

The more symmetry classification of mass matrix was presented in Ref. ryu, , and one may to the reference for details.

The Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} dimerization corresponds to the fermion bilinear residing on the opposite ends of nearest bond with a wave vector connecting two Dirac points, which can be realized in terms of τ1​σ0subscript𝜏1subscript𝜎0\tau_{1}\sigma_{0} and τ2​σ0subscript𝜏2subscript𝜎0\tau_{2}\sigma_{0}. Such modulation preserve SLS, the associated mass matrix named Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order pattern in analogy to the quantum dimer model. Since there are four spin matrices(Three Pauli matrix and a identity matrix), we have total eight Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS mass matrices(see table-I). Any modulation with lattice fermion sitting on the same sublattice does not preserve SLS, the electron patter corresponds to chage density wave, spin density wave, quantum Hall effect, and spin-orbital coupling driven quantum spin Hall effect. The total 16 mass matrices and the corresponding physical explanation were listed in table-I.

III Competition orders, WZW term and duality

Near the two sides of the quantum critical point(QCP), the two ordered phases break different symmetry and the continuous phase transition associate with two competing orders. Once suppressing one of the orders, which necessarily leads to the emergence of another order. The above features may embodies in the isotropic non-linear sigma model with a topological term (for example Wess-Zumino-Witten term and mutual Chern-Smions termkou2 ; vish2 ). We will see that the crucial feature of the theory is the existence of anticommutating mass terms and mutual duality, which may play key role in the understand of Landau-forbidden quantum criticality.

In this section, we discuss the typical Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS quantum phase transition. To describe the competition between the antiferromagnetic and Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS state, we include the five components Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS unit vector n→=ϕ→/|ϕ→|→𝑛→italic-ϕ→italic-ϕ\vec{n}=\vec{\phi}/|\vec{\phi}|, with the constraint |n→|2=1superscript→𝑛21|\vec{n}|^{2}=1,

ϕ→≡(N→,ReVBS, ImVBS).→italic-ϕ→𝑁ReVBS, ImVBS\vec{\phi}\equiv(\vec{N},\text{ReVBS, ImVBS}). (15)

The O​(3)×U​(1)𝑂3𝑈1O(3)\times U(1) vector(defined on S4superscript𝑆4S^{4} surface) in (2+1)d spacetime do not have topological nontrivial configurations for π3​(S4)=0subscript𝜋3superscript𝑆40\pi_{3}(S^{4})=0, but it support pertubative topological term due to non-triviality of the homotopy group π4​(S4)=Zsubscript𝜋4superscript𝑆4𝑍\pi_{4}(S^{4})=Z, which is known as WZW term. Considering the action

The appearance of the WZW topological term is the consequence of the duality between Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el and Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order, implying that the topological objects of one phase carries the quantum number of another phase(see follow for details). From above derivations, the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS QCP is obtained by incorporating the WZW term to the S​O​(5)𝑆𝑂5SO(5) nonlinear sigma model.

The Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el order breaks the S​U​(2)𝑆𝑈2SU(2) spin rotation to U​(1)𝑈1U(1) symmetry, then the O​(3)𝑂3O(3) vector n→=(n1,n2,n3)→𝑛subscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2subscript𝑛3\vec{n}=(n_{1},n_{2},n_{3}) for Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el order should be defined on S​U​(2)/U​(1)=S2𝑆𝑈2𝑈1superscript𝑆2SU(2)/U(1)=S^{2}. The Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS breaks C6subscript𝐶6C_{6} lattice rotation or lattice translational symmetry, if one consider the complex Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order parameter, the discrete symmetry may be enlarged to a enhanced U​(1)𝑈1U(1) symmetry. As discussed in superfluid phase transition or XY model, for the symmetry unrelated phase transition, each ordered phase can be driven by the condensation of the topological defect of the ordered phase. The Skyrmion is precisely mapped to a ”magnetic” flux quantum. Since the Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order parameter preserve U​(1)𝑈1U(1), it support topological defect in the form of vortex. In the dual description of vortex defect in the Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order, the vorticity play the role of ”electric” charge

Thus, the charge-vortex duality is captured by the mutual CS term, or WZW term in terms of order vector.

Now, let us turn to describe the phase transition. As shown in Eq.(20), the Skyrmion is conserved, it correspond to configuration of aμsubscript𝑎𝜇a_{\mu} at which creats a 2​π2𝜋2\pi flux. Once the quantum flux is condensed, the extra term induced by mutual CS is non-vanished, i.e., ∫d2​x​𝑑τ​ϵμ​ν​λ​∂μfb​⟨∂νaλ⟩≠0superscript𝑑2𝑥differential-d𝜏superscriptitalic-ϵ𝜇𝜈𝜆subscript𝜇superscript𝑓𝑏delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝜈subscript𝑎𝜆0\int d^{2}xd\tau\epsilon^{\mu\nu\lambda}\partial_{\mu}f^{b}\langle\partial_{\nu}a_{\lambda}\rangle\neq 0. The flux condensation destroys the Skyrmion number, meanwhile, it spontaneously breaks the U​(1)b𝑈subscript1𝑏U(1)_{b} symmetry and leads to the Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order. The condensation of vortex in Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order gives ⟨bμ⟩≠0delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑏𝜇0\langle b_{\mu}\rangle\neq 0, such condensation is irrelevent to the gauge condition: ∫d2​x​𝑑τ​ϵμ​ν​λ​∂ν∂λfa​⟨bμ⟩=0superscript𝑑2𝑥differential-d𝜏superscriptitalic-ϵ𝜇𝜈𝜆subscript𝜈subscript𝜆superscript𝑓𝑎delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑏𝜇0\int d^{2}xd\tau\epsilon^{\mu\nu\lambda}\partial_{\nu}\partial_{\lambda}f^{a}\langle b_{\mu}\rangle=0, it does not destroy conservation law

∂μjaμ=0.subscript𝜇subscriptsuperscript𝑗𝜇𝑎0\partial_{\mu}j^{\mu}_{a}=0. (24)

The spinon fields zαsubscript𝑧𝛼z_{\alpha} preserve the U​(1)a𝑈subscript1𝑎U(1)_{a} symmetry and whose condensation defined on S​U​(2)/U​(1)=S2𝑆𝑈2𝑈1superscript𝑆2SU(2)/U(1)=S^{2}, which is equivalent to Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el order.

As discussed by Xu in Ref. xu, , the Skyrmion of Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el order carries the quantum number of Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order, the condensate of Skyrmion breaks Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el order and it also induces Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order. To make the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS duality explicitly, we parametrize the order vector n→→𝑛\vec{n} as

n→=[ϕ​(r)​v→,1−ϕ2​(r)​s→​(τ,ρ)],→𝑛italic-ϕ𝑟→𝑣1superscriptitalic-ϕ2𝑟→𝑠𝜏𝜌\vec{n}=[\phi(r)\vec{v}\mathbf{,}\sqrt{1-\phi^{2}(r)}\vec{s}(\tau,\rho)], (25)

with ϕ​(0)=0italic-ϕ00\phi(0)=0 and ϕ​(∞)=1italic-ϕ1\phi(\infty)=1. Integrating over the space lead to the effective action near the core of vortex defect,

Sv=i4​∫𝑑τ​𝑑ρ​ϵα​β​ϵa​b​c​sa​(∂αsb)​(∂βsc),superscript𝑆v𝑖4differential-d𝜏differential-d𝜌superscriptitalic-ϵ𝛼𝛽superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑎𝑏𝑐subscript𝑠𝑎subscript𝛼subscript𝑠𝑏subscript𝛽subscript𝑠𝑐S^{\text{v}}=\frac{i}{4}\int d\tau d\rho\epsilon^{\alpha\beta}\epsilon^{abc}s_{a}(\partial_{\alpha}s_{b})(\partial_{\beta}s_{c}), (26)

which is right the WZW term for a 1/2121/2-spin in (0+1)D, that is 1/2121/2-spinon. Therefore, the vortex defect carries the 1/2121/2-spinon quantum number. It’s known that the Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order enjoy the spectral reflection, symmetry and the vortex defect host single fermionic midgap zero energy mode in the core. If the system preserve the time-reversal symmetry, the Kramers conjugation ensure that there are two zero energy levels, each carries up 1/2121/2-spinon quantum number and down 1/2121/2-spinon quantum number, repectively. The occupation of these zero modes leads to fractionalization of electrons, which gives the following four types of states:

f(+1/2↑,+1/2↓)(Δ​Q=1,Sz=0),f(−1/2↑,−1/2↓)(Δ​Q=−1,Sz=0),f(+1/2↑,−1/2↓)(Δ​Q=0,Sz=1/2),f(−1/2↑,+1/2↓)(Δ​Q=0,Sz=−1/2).\displaystyle\begin{split}f(+1/2\uparrow,+1/2\downarrow)&(\Delta Q=1,S_{z}=0),\\ f(-1/2\uparrow,-1/2\downarrow)&(\Delta Q=-1,S_{z}=0),\\ f(+1/2\uparrow,-1/2\downarrow)&(\Delta Q=0,S_{z}=1/2),\\ f(-1/2\uparrow,+1/2\downarrow)&(\Delta Q=0,S_{z}=-1/2).\end{split} (27)

The states are right the spin-charge separation holon, chargeon, and the two spinon states studied in quantum spin Hall effectran ; qi1 , and all the viewed particles are bosons. The self duality also result to spin-charge separation. Moreover, the condenses of these bosons will help us understand the rich phase transition like spin liquid-magnetic, superconductor-magnetic transition, etc.

By using sign-free Majorana quantum Monte Carlo simulations, Ref. yao, show the evidences of deconfined QCP between antiferromagnetic and Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS transition. Based on present understands, the WZW term or mutual CS term guarantee the duality between Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el and Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order, and the phase transition is described by the fractionalized fields zαsubscript𝑧𝛼z_{\alpha}. Therefore, we conclude that the QCP between Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS transition is deconfined, and such QCP may be generized to other multiple-components order parameter.

IV The index theorem and Neel-Kekule-VBS duality

The WZW term exhibits mutual duality between Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el and Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order, we now turn our attention to how the duality relate to index of the topological excitation. For the system with chiral symmetry, there exist a index theorem relate the topological stability to the number of the zero modes hosting by the topological excitation. Here we first briefly review the Jackiw-Rossi-like mode and the index theorem. And beyond any symmetry, the topological index for twisted order is discussed in the sense of Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS duality.

IV.1 The nontrivial twisted order pattern

The Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order pattern corresponds to the modulation of fermion bilinear operator with different sublattice and Dirac point, and thus preserve chiral symmetry. Without considering the spin degrees of freedom, if ψ𝜓\psi enter as the Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS mass matrix, the matrix fields V=a​bψ†ℳa​bψ{}_{ab}=\psi^{\dagger}\mathcal{M}_{ab}\psi condenses, for instance

⟨V10⟩=|Δ|​⟨ψt​τ1​σ0​ψ⟩≠0,delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑉10Δdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜓𝑡subscript𝜏1subscript𝜎0𝜓0\left\langle V_{10}\right\rangle=|\Delta|\left\langle\psi^{t}\tau_{1}\sigma_{0}\psi\right\rangle\neq 0, (28)

such condenses gapped out the nodal quasiparticles. In order to demonstrate the connection between the twist Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order pattern and midgap zero energy states at the Dirac equation level, it’s useful to suppose that the order pattern could be slowly varying on the scale of the lattice spacing, and the nontrivial background topology will be realized by the complex valued mass matrix field. In continuum limit, the complex Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS mass matrix as V=𝑉absentV=ReV𝑉V+i𝑖iImV𝑉V, with ReV𝑉V=Δ​⟨ψt​τ1​σ0​ψ⟩absentΔdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜓𝑡subscript𝜏1subscript𝜎0𝜓=\Delta\left\langle\psi^{t}\tau_{1}\sigma_{0}\psi\right\rangle and ImV𝑉V=Δ​⟨ψt​τ2​σ0​ψ⟩absentΔdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜓𝑡subscript𝜏2subscript𝜎0𝜓=\Delta\left\langle\psi^{t}\tau_{2}\sigma_{0}\psi\right\rangle. Thus, the fermion interacting with the twist Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order according to the Lagrangian

LVBSsubscript𝐿VBS\displaystyle L_{\text{VBS}} =\displaystyle= ψ¯​γμ​(i​∂μ+γ5​aμ)​ψ−ψ¯​β​V​ψ,¯𝜓superscript𝛾𝜇𝑖subscript𝜇subscript𝛾5subscript𝑎𝜇𝜓¯𝜓𝛽𝑉𝜓\displaystyle\bar{\psi}\gamma^{\mu}(i\partial_{\mu}+\gamma_{5}a_{\mu})\psi-\bar{\psi}\beta V\psi,

The phase twist in such Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS mass matrix realize domain wall or vortex at two dimensional spatial, indeed, the background topology for the Lagrangian equal to the Jackiw-Rossi model that describe charged fermion interacting with the scalar fields of the two dimensional Abelian Higgs model.

It’s known that the soliton excitations are associated with many profound physical phenomena like Fractionalization, topological degeneracy and zero energy quasiparticle. The occupation of zero energy soliton lead to spin-charge separation, before discussing the wavefunction of the zero mode solutions, we first make some discussion about the Lagrangian LVBSsubscript𝐿VBSL_{\text{VBS}} and the Fu-Kane model that describe the surface of topological insulator with a conventional superconductor proximity to it in terms of the Hamiltonian

When the chemical potential satisfy μ>|Δ|,𝜇Δ\mu>|\Delta|, due to the ℤ2subscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}_{2} topological index, there is at least one topologically protected zero mode localized on the odd vorticity vortex. When μ=0,𝜇0\mu=0, the massive vortex (non-trivial twist of background field) also guarantee the existence of zero modes and now the model equal to LVBSsubscript𝐿VBSL_{\text{VBS}}.

Many literatures have studied the single-valued and normalizable wave functions for zero energy solution in the presence of nontrivial twist fields. For |n|𝑛|n|-twisted order parameter, there are |n|𝑛|n| independent normalizable zero energy states, the property and the special form for each zero energy solution may differ. The Hamiltonian subjected to the Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order pattern is given by

and the normalizable zero energy solutions have been discussed in appendix B. When the degree of twisting for the Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order equal to 2​k2𝑘2k, there are 2​k2𝑘2k normalizable zero modes, and each zero energy mode spinors characterized by two phase dependence ψ𝐤​a=f​ei​l1​θ+g​ei​l2​θsubscript𝜓𝐤𝑎𝑓superscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑙1𝜃𝑔superscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑙2𝜃\psi_{\mathbf{k}a}=fe^{il_{1}\theta}+ge^{il_{2}\theta} (l1≠l2subscript𝑙1subscript𝑙2l_{1}\neq l_{2} or m1≠m2subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2m_{1}\neq m_{2}); When the whole twist of the Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order equal to 2​k+12𝑘12k+1, there are 2​k+12𝑘12k+1 zero modes, among which only one for single phase dependence(l1=l2)l_{1}=l_{2}) and the others characterized by two phase dependence. The normalizable single phase dependence wave function for zero mode on sublattice-a can be easily obtained as

ψ𝐤​a=𝒩a​e−∫0r(Δ​(r)+2​n​a​(r)−(n−1)2​r)​𝑑r​ei​[(n−1)​θ2−π4],ψ𝐤′​a=i​ψ¯𝐤​a.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜓𝐤𝑎subscript𝒩𝑎superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript0𝑟Δ𝑟2𝑛𝑎𝑟𝑛12𝑟differential-d𝑟superscript𝑒𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1𝜃2𝜋4subscript𝜓superscript𝐤′𝑎𝑖subscript¯𝜓𝐤𝑎\begin{split}\psi_{\mathbf{k}a}&=\mathcal{N}_{a}e^{-\int_{0}^{r}(\Delta(r)+\frac{2na(r)-(n-1)}{2r})dr}e^{i[\frac{(n-1)\theta}{2}-\frac{\pi}{4}]},\\ \psi_{\mathbf{k^{\prime}}a}&=i\bar{\psi}_{\mathbf{k}a}.\end{split} (32)

Since Δ​(r)Δ𝑟\Delta(r) and a​(r)𝑎𝑟a(r) vanish at small r𝑟r, the wave function to be normalizable require n≤−1𝑛1n\leq-1. Similarly, the normalizable single-phase dependence zero mode on sublattice-b as

ψ𝐤​b=𝒩b​e−∫0r(Δ​(r)+(n+1)−2​n​a​(r)2​r)​𝑑r​ei​[(n+1)​θ2+π4],ψ𝐤′​b=−i​ψ¯𝐤​b.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜓𝐤𝑏subscript𝒩𝑏superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript0𝑟Δ𝑟𝑛12𝑛𝑎𝑟2𝑟differential-d𝑟superscript𝑒𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1𝜃2𝜋4subscript𝜓superscript𝐤′𝑏𝑖subscript¯𝜓𝐤𝑏\begin{split}\psi_{\mathbf{k}b}&=\mathcal{N}_{b}e^{-\int_{0}^{r}(\Delta(r)+\frac{(n+1)-2na(r)}{2r})dr}e^{i[\frac{(n+1)\theta}{2}+\frac{\pi}{4}]},\\ \psi_{\mathbf{k^{\prime}}b}&=-i\bar{\psi}_{\mathbf{k}b}.\end{split} (33)

The wave function at small r𝑟r to be normalizable require n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1, and same condition can be seen from Ref. mudry, . Since the sublattice symmetry (or named chiral symmetry), the zero mode wave function on sublattice-a also hold on sublattice-b with the substitutions ψ𝐤​a→ψ𝐤​b→subscript𝜓𝐤𝑎subscript𝜓𝐤𝑏\psi_{\mathbf{k}a}\rightarrow\psi_{\mathbf{k}b} and n→−n→𝑛𝑛n\rightarrow-n. The chiral operation is defined as Γ5=τ3​σ3subscriptΓ5subscript𝜏3subscript𝜎3\Gamma_{5}=\tau_{3}\sigma_{3}, which gives Γ5​ψa/b=±1subscriptΓ5subscript𝜓𝑎𝑏plus-or-minus1\Gamma_{5}\psi_{a/b}=\pm 1. The sublattice symmetry ensure that the energy eigenstate ±Eplus-or-minus𝐸\pm E come into pairs, thus the zero modes bound to the VBS vortex are classified by ℤ2subscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}_{2}. Only for odd twisting, there is at least a topologically protected Fermion zero mode. If the system possess particle-hole symmetry, which will lead to Majorana zero mode, such as topological superconductor studied in Ref. cheng, .

IV.2 The topological index and the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS duality

The index theorem bridge the total number and the topological stability of the zero modes, which relate the analytical index of a Dirac operator to the the winding number of background scalar field in 2D spatial. It’s easily show that the Hamiltonian in Eq.(31) connect with an elliptic differential operator for vanishing energy. For the system with chiral symmetry, the mid-gap states are always come into pairs, and the difference between the number of zero mode with opposite chirality give the analytical index ind​H=n+−n−ind𝐻subscript𝑛subscript𝑛\text{ind}H=n_{+}-n_{-}. The eigen function for vanishing energy is

σ2​(i​∂1+a1)​ψ−σ1​(i​∂2+a2)​ψ+Δ​σ2​ψ∗=0.subscript𝜎2𝑖subscript1subscript𝑎1𝜓subscript𝜎1𝑖subscript2subscript𝑎2𝜓Δsubscript𝜎2superscript𝜓∗0\sigma_{2}(i\partial_{1}+a_{1})\psi-\sigma_{1}(i\partial_{2}+a_{2})\psi+\Delta\sigma_{2}\psi^{\ast}=0.

By writing ψ​(x)𝜓𝑥\psi(x) as two real function ψ​(x)=ψ1​(x)+i​ψ2​(x)𝜓𝑥subscript𝜓1𝑥𝑖subscript𝜓2𝑥\psi(x)=\psi_{1}(x)+i\psi_{2}(x), and expressing Δ=Δ1+i​Δ2ΔsubscriptΔ1𝑖subscriptΔ2\Delta=\Delta_{1}+i\Delta_{2}, the corresponding differential operator is of the form

𝒟=(−∂2−i​τ2​∂1)+(a1−i​τ2​a2)+(τ3​Δ1+τ1​Δ2)𝒟subscript2𝑖subscript𝜏2subscript1subscript𝑎1𝑖subscript𝜏2subscript𝑎2subscript𝜏3subscriptΔ1subscript𝜏1subscriptΔ2\mathcal{D}=(-\partial_{2}-i\tau_{2}\partial_{1})+(a_{1}-i\tau_{2}a_{2})+(\tau_{3}\Delta_{1}+\tau_{1}\Delta_{2})

The index theorem for 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} gives the analytical indexweinberg .

The index theorem is applicable only when the system preserve chiral symmetry. Beyond chiral symmetry, the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS duality provide us an alternative way to derive topological index via dual topological excitation. For present (2+1)D Dirac fermion interacting with the background scalar fields(complex Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS order), the dual target space can be obtained by considering the extended order parameter ϕ=(\phi=( ReΔ,Δ\Delta,ImΔ,h)\Delta,h) according to the Lagrangian

L=ψ¯​i​γμ​(∂μ−i​γ5​aμ)​ψ−ψ¯​(∑k=13Γk​ϕk)​ψ.𝐿¯𝜓𝑖superscript𝛾𝜇subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝛾5subscript𝑎𝜇𝜓¯𝜓superscriptsubscript𝑘13subscriptΓ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘𝜓L=\bar{\psi}i\gamma^{\mu}(\partial_{\mu}-i\gamma_{5}a_{\mu})\psi-\bar{\psi}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{3}\Gamma_{k}\phi_{k}\right)\psi. (34)

As shown in appendix C, the topological current

and the topological number Q=∫d2​x​J0𝑄superscript𝑑2𝑥superscript𝐽0Q=\int d^{2}xJ^{0} classifies all the homotopy classes π2​(S2)subscript𝜋2superscript𝑆2\pi_{2}(S^{2}), which is equivalent to the degrees of mapping from T2superscript𝑇2T^{2} to S2superscript𝑆2S^{2}. We suppose the VBS vortex ϕv=(\phi_{v}=(ReΔ,Δ\Delta,ImΔ)\Delta) lie on the plane where h=0ℎ0h=0. this quantum number gives the difference between the number of zero mode with opposite chirality, from which the number of zero modes can be identified. Thus, the analytic index of a Dirac operator relate to a topological index of an associate mapping in its dual topological defect, at least valid for present case. The Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e}-VBS duality imply that there exist an invariant connects the following two theories:

V Conclusions and discussion

In conclusion, motivated by the predictable conclusion that the quantum critical point between Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} valence-bond-solid(VBS) and antiferromagnetic is deconfined in Ref. yao, , we have studied the dynamical spontaneous symmetry breaking in two dimensional graphene Dirac semimetal, and discussed the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS mutual duality and the quantum transition between them. We consider the general quartic fermion-bilinear interactions that will generate rich order parameters when the dynamical symmetry is broken. One feature in our study is the appearance of multicritical point for various orders, which is shown to irrelevant to the special form of quartic fermion-bilinear but only depends on the dimensions of the mass matrix(each mass matrix corresponds to an order parameter). The multicritical point exhibits the Landau-forbidden quantum phase transition, and the key ingredient is the anticommutativity among these mass matrices. Very recently, we observed that Ref. ass, have numerically shown the multicritical and the continuous Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS transition, which is consistent with our results.

Further, we have shown that the typical Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS quantum criticality can be understood in term of the mutual duality between them. By using the ’superspin’ non-linear sigma field theory, the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS quantum criticality is captured by the WZW action or self BF Chern-Simons field theory, which reveal the mutual duality for Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el and Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS order. Statically speaking, the mutual duality in the sense that the topological defect in either phase carries the quantum number of another phase. Dynamically, the mutual duality in the sense that the order parameter in either phases carries the symmetry of another phase, which embodies in the Chern-Simons action. The breaking of symmetry in one phase meanwhile breaks the dual symmetry and lead to the emergence of another order. Since the transition is described by the CP(1) fields coupled with U​(1)𝑈1U(1) gauge field, the quantum critical point for Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} transition is deconfined. We also saw that the mutual duality lead to the profound phenomenon of spin-charge separation, and the concept of duality may help us understand more rich physics.

We now make some comments about the concept of duality. The Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS duality in present paper means self-duality near two sides of the critical point rather than duality between two seemingly different theories. Various recent study concentrate on the duality between the theoretical fields theory in high-energy physics and the quantum criticality in condensate physics. For example, the Nf=2subscript𝑁𝑓2N_{f}=2 noncompact QED3 and the easy-plane U​(1)𝑈1U(1) noncompact CP1 modelmzy ; cwang (describing the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-VBS transition in magnets with XY spin symmetry), the QED3-Gross-Neveu model and S​U​(2)𝑆𝑈2SU(2) noncompact CP1 modelhyc . The duality in the sense that both two theories are described by the same effective low-energy field theory and are characterized by same critical behavior at criticality. The hidden duality relate the interacting driven topological quantum phase transition and the quantum criticality, and which will deepen our consensus for the fundament.

Finally, let us give a summary and prospect for Landau-forbidden quantum criticality, which features the follows: (i) Two phases are symmetry-incompatible. (ii) There exist mutual duality between the two phases, as stated in the above. (iii) The space-time topological excitations must be involved in the phase transition process. (iv) The phase transition from phase-B to phase-A may destroy some structure(like entanglement or interacting symmetry protected topological phase) belong to the phase-B. The study of FIQCyao and symmetric mass generation(many-body gapyyz ) give some new insights for us, and the duality might shed some light on this topic. More, the surface realization of Landau-beyond quantum criticality for strong correlated topological states in high dimensional is also an interesting issue to be explored.

This appendix is aim to derive the low energy effective theory for the Ne´´𝑒\acute{e}el-Kekule´´𝑒\acute{e} VBS SO(5) order parameters. The index theorem state that the analytical index is identical to the the number of zero modes, and also identical to the winding number of the background fields. Here the normalizable zero mode is given by ψ0=(ψ𝐤​a,ψ𝐤​b,ψ𝐤′​b,ψ𝐤′​a)tsubscript𝜓0superscriptsubscript𝜓𝐤𝑎subscript𝜓𝐤𝑏subscript𝜓superscript𝐤′𝑏subscript𝜓superscript𝐤′𝑎𝑡\psi_{0}=(\psi_{\mathbf{k}a},\psi_{\mathbf{k}b},\psi_{\mathbf{k^{\prime}}b},\psi_{\mathbf{k^{\prime}}a})^{t}.
